Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Pilot Study of Simultaneous Parameter and State Estimation in Coupled Ocean-Atmosphere General Circulation Models Using the Ensemble Kalman Filter
Award.AbstractNarration: Ocean Atmosphere General Circulation Models (OAGCM) exhibit significant model biases, e.g., the tropical bias in the Intertropical Convergence Zone cold tongue complex. A significant part of such biases is due to uncertainties in the model parameters. Thus far, however, parameter tuning in OAGCMs remains rudimentary. This collaborative project will develop a novel strategy for systematic parameter optimization in OAGCMs, using an ensemble based data assimilation strategy, focusing on the outstanding tropical bias problem. Building on an existing coupled data assimilation system, an adaptive coupled ensemble Kalman Filter system (AcEnKF) for a simultaneous estimation of model parameter and state, will be developed. Different assimilation techniques to search for an effective method of parameter optimization in OAGCMs will be studied, as also coupled dynamics relevant to parameter optimization in the tropical climate system for both the climatology and climate variability. The work is expected to give the first comprehensive evaluation of the ensemble based strategy for parameter optimization in OAGCMs. The study will also shed light on the mechanism of the coupled dynamics of the tropical climate system and its sensitivity to model parameters. In spite of potential difficulties, this pilot study represents a significant step forward in the improvement of OAGCMs. This activity has significant broader impacts: it will lay a foundation for a systematic improvement of OAGCMs and, more generally, future coupled earth system models.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One great challenge for future climate project is a systematic model bias in almost all state-of-the-art complex climate models, or the so called Coupled General Circulation Model (CGCM). Even After half a century of efforts, there has been no systematic strategy to reduce the model bias. Here, we propose to explore a systematic strategy to reduce model biases by optimizig the model parameters systematically using observations, i.e. the data assimilatioin approach. The idea is that the bias in model parameters will cause biases in model state variables, such as temperauture, therefore, its error relative to the observation can also be used to infer the bias in moel parameters. The implementation of this idea has remained challenge because of the complexity of the CGCM and the required data assimilation method in the past.Recent studies however have shown a new method of data assimilation, the ensemble Kalman Filter (EnKF) method, which has made it practical to perform data assimilation in a CGCM and therefore for parameter optimization.

We have made signifianct progresses in developing EnKF schemes in CGCMs and for parameter optimization. One of the highlights is the first successful EnKF parameter estimation in two CGCMs in the perfect model framework. As an example, in the CGCM FOAM, a 30-member EnKF parameter estimation is shown in Fig.1. The parameter to be estimated is related to the depth of solar penetration, which has the truth of 17-m. The sea surface temperature and salinity observations are used for assimiation once every month. The obsevations are then used for assimilation first on the state variable in the first two years, and then,  for estimating the parameter using a new method Adaptive Spatial Average (ASA). The ASA uses the ensemble spread as the criterion for selecting "good" values from the spatially varing posterior paraeter estimations, which will then be averaged to give the final globally uniform paraemter. This method has been extended successfully to the GFDL CM2.1 model. Our study demosntrate the feasibility to correct model parameters in a CGCM, which then lay the foundation for the future work of a systematic optimization of parameters in climate models.
